text:
Thank you for your interest
in Harvard Business School.

This session will
provide a brief overview
of the MBA program.

Whether it's
reimagining capitalism,

tackling climate change,
embracing artificial

intelligence, or grappling
with data and privacy,

the most pressing challenges
and interesting opportunities

facing the world today cannot
be addressed without business
playing a significant role.

Harvard Business School
has been educating leaders

to make a difference
in the world

since 1908, inspiring
them to apply

the broad and specific general
management skills needed

to improve government,
education, health

care, nonprofit, and nearly
every aspect of industry
and commerce worldwide.

HBS graduates are located
all over the world,

and they are using
their MBA education

to follow their passion and
make impact in the areas that
are of most importance to them.

HBS offers a two-year full-time
MBA in General Management.

The General Management
perspective is so important

because business decisions
are interconnected,

and leaders need a
comprehensive understanding

of all aspects of
an organization
to make it run successfully.

Through the general
management curriculum,

you will learn the
hard and soft skills

needed to lead organizations
whatever the discipline,

collaborate across functions,
and make a significant impact
as a leader.

The first year at HBS is
the required curriculum,

which provides a strong
foundation in business

fundamentals and is focused on
developing a general management
perspective.

First-year courses addressed the
role of the individual leader,

the organization being led,
and the broader context

in which leaders and
organizations operate.

You'll take
semester-long courses

like finance, marketing,
technology and operations,

and strategy, as well
as short-form courses,

like the social purpose
of the firm and inclusion.

The second year at HBS is
the elective curriculum

with over 100 electives
to choose from,

as well as the opportunity
to cross-register

with other schools and to
take on independent projects.

You decide what you take
your second year, as well
as your approach.

Are you looking for
depth, breadth, or both?

The HBS MBA is not just
a two-year proposition.

It is a community that
you are part of for life.

The 89,000-plus alumni
network supports each other,

as well as current students as
they explore different career
options and geographies.

Alumni are in over
173 countries,

with over 30% living
outside the United States.

HBS provides lifelong
learning opportunities

and connects alumni to
valuable programs, services,

and resources within HBS to
drive professional and life
success.

To solve today's
challenges, the world

needs a new type of leader
who can tackle tough problems,

bring innovation to old debates,
and embody sound ethics.

Becoming this type of leader
requires hard work, humility,

and a willingness to make
mistakes and change course.

HBS prepares you
to be this leader.

HBS challenges you
to think differently.

At HBS, we use a variety
of dynamic and interactive

teaching methods that
require active participation,

preparation, and
openness to change.

The case method, which is
our most well-known approach,

involves discussing real
life business challenges.

Rather than textbooks, each
case is 10 to 15 pages,

providing context
on the business

and culminating in
a pivotal decision.

In the real world and
in the case method,
the answers are not clear-cut.

The professor asks,
what would you do?

And the class
discusses and debates
the answers and the issues.

Students graduate from HBS not
only with increased business

acumen, but with
grounding and practice

and how to make
difficult decisions,

and what it means
to assume leadership
in a global environment.

The HBS field method
complements the case method,

and all first-year
students participate

in a yearlong
course called FIELD.

The course includes
FIELD global immersion,

where students work with
a global partner company

to apply what they've learned
to real world business problems.

The course culminates
in a one-week immersion

at the company's location,
during which students

meet with their global
partner and local customers.

Beyond FIELD global
immersion, you'll

expand your global mindset
every day via what you study--

over half of all cases have
an international focus--
and who you study with--

more than one third
of the MBA class

is comprised of
international students.

At HBS, you'll broaden
your global perspective.

Business is inherently
global, and it is important

that our students understand a
rapidly changing dynamic world.

During your first
year at HBS, you

will be assigned to a section
of approximately 90 students.

The section is a microcosm
of the broader class.

It's similar to hiring for a
company or assembling a team.

We bring together a
broad representation

of perspectives, of industry
skills and experiences,
and personality types.

This rich diversity of thought
fuels our case discussions

and helps you build
interpersonal skills
throughout your first year.

You'll prep for case
discussions together.
You'll study together.

You'll get to know
one another and count

on each other for new insights
to help broaden understanding.

For those of you interested
in pursuing two degrees

to meet your dual interests,
we offer joint degree programs

with other Harvard
graduate schools.

These joint degree
programs allow a student

to complete two
degrees in less time

than being enrolled
in them separately.

You will still go through
the HBS required curriculum

and be part of the same section
and first-year experience
as all MBA students.

Each program also has its
own special curriculum

that will impact
your elective year,

and they have their own
application processes.

Our two newest joint
degree programs

are the MS/MBA in
engineering sciences, which

focuses on building tech
ventures and entrepreneurship,

and our MS/MBA biotechnology
life sciences, which focuses

on transforming medical
discoveries at the intersection
of business and ethics.

If you have an interest in any
of these joint degree programs,

please see the website
for more information.

Academics are paramount
to the HBS experience.

However, your education
is not just contained
to the classroom.

The transformation of your
potential into leadership

is realized through every
aspect of the HBS experience.

To explore student life here
is to investigate multiple ways

to learn, to
connect, and to lead.

Student clubs play an important
role in the student experience.

Most campus activities
are organized

by student clubs and the
Student Association, our student
government.

With more than 95 clubs and
over 200 leadership positions,

there are many ways for students
to refine their leadership

and organizational
management experience,

explore interests, make
friends, and just have fun.

Life and learning
at HBS takes place

on our beautiful
residential campus

in the heart of one of the
world's greatest cities--
Boston.

The HBS campus is 40 acres with
over 35 different buildings,

including 17 LEED-certified
buildings and nine green roofs.

HBS is the only top business
school in the United States

with a residential,
self-contained campus.

65% of our students
live on campus
in either dorms or apartments.

The campus design
serves to strengthen

the sense of community at
the school with the belief

that the daily interactions
of residential life

only increase the
potential for learning.

When you become part
of HBS, you will

join a community of
learners, and you

will have the
opportunity to interact

with inspiring people who share
this commitment to education
and community.

We are all invested in the
learning and development
of one another.

Partners and families are
an important part of the HBS

community too, and
are often active

in the extracurricular
life of the campus,

participating in section
life, clubs, and the Student
Association.

Achieving our mission requires
an environment of trust

and mutual respect, free
expression and inquiry,

and commitment to
truth, excellence,
and lifelong learning.

Community members accept these
principles when joining HBS.

In doing so, they agree
to abide by our community

values of respect, honesty and
integrity, and accountability.

Summer internships and post-HBS
career paths are top of mind

for many people when thinking
about a graduate degree.

At HBS, we recognize that every
career journey is different.

As a student, you'll
have the opportunity

to realize your
personal career vision,

develop a job search strategy,
and enrich your experience

with unparalleled career
education resources, hundreds

of events and
outstanding coaches.

Career and Professional
Development, known at HBS

as CPD, will work with you at
every stage of your HBS journey

no matter where your
experience may take you.

In your first year,
you will reflect

on your passions,
values, and goals,

and explore industries
and career paths

through various
programs and events.

You'll work with a
career coach from

your initial self-assessment
through the job search
and beyond.

A two-year MBA program
provides the unique opportunity

to pursue a summer internship
or your own venture.

Whether exploring a new
industry, function or location,

or furthering your pre-HBS
industry experience,

CPD has individualized resources
and company connections

to help you in your
summer opportunity search.

In your second year, you'll work
closely with your career coach

to continue to adjust based
on your summer experience.

You'll have access to on-campus
interviews, networking events,

and negotiation
resources to help you
towards your next step.

Even after graduation,
you'll have

lifelong access to
programming, events,

and career coaching designed
specifically for alumni.

For some people, their unique
career vision may be to found,
join, or invest in a startup.

HBS is a place where students
are encouraged and inspired

to pursue their
entrepreneurial passions.

There is a vast
ecosystem of resources

that supports the unique
needs of innovators,

both inside and
outside the classroom.

13% of our students start
their own venture right
after graduation.

Over half of our alumni over
the course of their careers

have been involved in
founding at least one company.

All students are exposed
to entrepreneurship

in the first year via a course
called the Entrepreneurial
Manager.

This course provides students
with an understanding of issues

facing entrepreneurs, and
an exposure to the skills
involved in addressing them.

Additionally,
first-year students

can participate in
Startup Boot Camp,

a short, intensive
program for those

who want to learn
the skills, tools,

and practices of rigorous
experimentation-driven
startups.

There are 53 faculty members in
the Entrepreneurial Management

Unit, which allows HBS to offer
many different elective courses

focused on entrepreneurship
for second-year students.

The Rock Center is the hub
of entrepreneurship at HBS,

offering programming
and resources
to students and alumni.

This includes things the
New Venture Competition,

where students and alumni
can test their ideas

and get feedback from
industry experts.

The competition includes
both a business track
and social enterprise track.

And our
Entrepreneur-in-Residence

program, which includes around
40 accomplished founders

with deep industry
experience, funders,

and lawyers who are on campus
to be mentors to our students.

Additionally, the Rock
Center collaborates

with MBA financial aid to
assist students who wish
to pursue startup interests.

One way is through the
Rock Summer Fellows,

which provides funding and
virtual workshops for students

pursuing entrepreneurship
during the summer
between first and second year.

Another way is to the
Rock Loan Forgiveness

Program, which offers a
one time need-based award
of up to $20,000.

At HBS, you are going to learn
from and with a diverse cohort
of talented peers.

You are going to be challenged
to engage and to change
the way you think about issues.

You'll be a different
person when you emerge--

someone who can
think on their feet,

navigate uncertainty,
and make decisions
in high-stakes situations.

You'll be a leader who can
make a difference in the world.
